elements.title: Crowd Range Indicator: Minimal Visual for Price-in-Context Display
elements.problem: The pricing interface currently presents the host's price in isolation -- a number in a field with no visual context. Anthony set $3,000/month without seeing how it compares to other hosts. Surowiecki demonstrates that crowd estimates are most effective when individual participants can see where they stand relative to the aggregate. But the visual must be radically simple: Anthony (AOL email, monosyllabic communicator) will not process a chart, a histogram, or a data table. The visual challenge is to communicate 'your price vs. the crowd' in under 2 seconds of visual scanning, using the Split Lease purple palette, without adding visual noise to the pricing step.
elements.solution: Design a crowd range indicator as a single horizontal bar with three elements: (1) A thin bar in --bg-light-gray spanning the crowd price range (e.g., $2,600-$3,400). (2) A filled segment in --secondary-purple from the low end to the host's price position, showing where they fall. (3) The host's price displayed above the bar in --text-dark at --text-lg weight --font-weight-bold. The range endpoints displayed at bar ends in --text-light-gray at --text-sm. The entire component is a single line, no taller than 40px, fitting within the existing pricing field's vertical rhythm. No interaction needed: it is a passive display element. On SMS-based pricing confirmations, the visual equivalent is a text string: '$3,000/mo (range: $2,600-$3,400)' -- no image needed.

evidence.quote: It would be 3000 for the month... Is that right? Yes.
evidence.insight: Anthony processed pricing as a single number confirmation. The visual must match this simplicity: one number (his price), one context element (the range), zero interaction required.

evidence.quote: The crowd had guessed that the ox would weigh 1,197 pounds. The ox weighed 1,198 pounds.
evidence.insight: Galton's result was communicated as a single comparison: crowd estimate vs. actual. The pricing indicator must achieve the same clarity: host price vs. crowd range. Two data points, one visual relationship.

evidence.quote: --success-green: #4B47CE (mapped to purple in Split Lease system). --secondary-purple: rgb(109, 49, 194).
evidence.insight: The range indicator must use the purple palette exclusively. The filled segment uses --secondary-purple for the host's position, and the unfilled range uses --bg-light-gray. No green, no red, no traffic-light semantics -- the indicator is contextual, not evaluative.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-white (#ffffff) = 16.1:1 (passes). --text-light-gray (#9ca3af) on --bg-white = 2.6:1 (fails AA for body text but acceptable for supplementary labels per WCAG 1.4.3 exception for incidental text). If improved per Paula Scher proposal, --text-light-gray becomes #8891A0 = 4.5:1 (passes AA).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The host's price is the dominant visual element (largest text, darkest color). The range bar is subordinate (thin, light gray). The range endpoints are tertiary (smallest text, lightest color). The eye should read: price first, position-on-bar second, range numbers third (if at all).
elements.brand_alignment: Uses the purple palette to reinforce that crowd data is a platform feature, not a third-party overlay. The --secondary-purple fill creates a sense of 'your position in the community' that aligns with Split Lease's cooperative brand values. Avoids evaluative colors (red/green) that would imply the host's price is right or wrong.

elements.title: Confirmation Card Pattern: Visual Language for Pre-Filled Data Review
elements.problem: When a passive host like Anthony encounters a pre-populated listing, the visual language must instantly signal 'review this' rather than 'create this.' Current listing wizard design uses empty input fields, placeholder text, and step indicators -- all visual signals of creation, not confirmation. The platform needs a distinct visual pattern for pre-filled data that communicates: 'We already know this about your space. Is it correct?' Surowiecki's framework supports this: in the Scorpion submarine search, Craven presented pre-formulated scenarios for confirmation, not blank hypotheses for generation. The visual must make the difference between 'fill this in' and 'confirm this' immediately apparent.
elements.solution: Design a Confirmation Card pattern with the following visual characteristics: (1) Background: --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255) -- the purple-tinted warm white) to distinguish from the standard --bg-white of creation forms. This subtle tint signals 'content already here.' (2) Each data point is displayed as a label-value pair in a compact row: label in --text-gray at --text-sm, value in --text-dark at --text-md --font-weight-semibold. (3) A small check icon (Feather: 'check-circle') in --secondary-purple appears left of each confirmed data point. (4) Data points that need attention (missing photos, unconfirmed fields) use an alert icon (Feather: 'alert-circle') in --accent-coral (#E85D4C from proposed palette, or --protocol-danger #DC3545 from current tokens). (5) The card has a --border-color (#e5e7eb) border with --rounded-xl (12px) radius and --shadow-sm elevation. (6) No step indicators, no progress bars, no 'Step 1 of 6' -- the card is a single, scrollable confirmation surface.

evidence.quote: Bryant confirms each data point sequentially: availability, price, utilities, deposit, laundry, parking. Anthony confirms each with 'Yes' or a short fact.
evidence.insight: The visual card must mirror the call's confirmation flow: data presented sequentially, each confirmable with a single visual gesture (the check icon represents Anthony's 'Yes'). The visual pattern is a translation of the phone call's interaction pattern into a screen layout.

evidence.quote: Craven concocted a series of scenarios -- alternative explanations for what might have happened to the Scorpion. Then he... asked each of them to offer his best guess about how likely each of the scenarios was.
evidence.insight: Craven pre-formulated scenarios for confirmation rather than asking for open-ended generation. The Confirmation Card similarly pre-formulates listing data for host confirmation. The visual must make it clear that the host is confirming pre-existing information, not generating new information.

evidence.quote: .card { background: var(--bg-white); border: var(--border-width-thin) solid var(--border-color); border-radius: var(--rounded-xl); padding: var(--spacing-2xl); box-shadow: var(--shadow-sm); }
evidence.insight: The standard card pattern provides the structural foundation. The Confirmation Card extends it with --bg-off-white background and check/alert icons to visually distinguish confirmation from creation.

spacing: --spacing-lg (gap between card header and first data row)
new_tokens_needed: --bg-confirmation: rgb(252, 250, 255) -- alias for --bg-off-white, semantically named for confirmation contexts

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) = approximately 15.5:1 (passes AAA). --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-off-white = approximately 4.5:1 (passes AA). --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) on --bg-off-white = approximately 5.8:1 (passes AA). --protocol-danger (#DC3545) on --bg-off-white = approximately 4.2:1 (borderline AA -- may need --status-error #C53030 from proposed palette at 6.1:1 for compliance).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Card header ('Your Listing Details') is the entry point. Eye then scans down the left column of icons: green checks confirm, alert icons flag action items. The icons create a vertical scanline that communicates overall completeness before the host reads any text. A card with all check icons says 'done' at a glance. A card with one alert icon says 'one thing needed.'
elements.brand_alignment: The --bg-off-white warm purple tint reinforces the Split Lease brand even in a utilitarian confirmation context. The --secondary-purple check icons connect the confirmation experience to the platform's interactive purple language. The pattern feels 'already part of the platform' rather than a third-party form.

elements.title: Host Engagement Spectrum: Visual Encoding for Agent Dashboard Host States
elements.problem: The agent dashboard (proposed in communicates-0932-004) needs a visual language to communicate host engagement levels at a glance. Agents manage portfolios of hosts with radically different engagement profiles: some log in daily, others (like Anthony) never log in at all. Without a clear visual encoding, the agent cannot quickly identify which hosts need attention. Surowiecki's framework shows that the 'diversity of opinion' condition requires tracking the full spectrum of participation -- from vocal to silent. The visual must encode this spectrum without implying that silent hosts are 'bad' and active hosts are 'good.' Anthony's silence is a valid participation mode, not a failure state.
elements.solution: Design a four-state engagement indicator using the purple gradient to encode engagement level. (1) Active (--secondary-purple, solid filled circle): Host logs in regularly, responds to messages, manages own listing. (2) Moderate (--accent-purple, half-filled circle): Host logs in occasionally, responds within 48 hours, partial self-management. (3) Passive (--text-light-gray, outlined circle with small fill): Host rarely logs in, responds only to SMS, relies on agent. (4) Silent (--border-color, empty outlined circle): Host has not responded to any communication in 14+ days. The visual is a small circle (20px, --icon-sm) that appears next to each host's name in the agent dashboard. The purple-to-gray gradient communicates 'level of platform presence' without red/green judgment. The agent scans the column of circles: solid purple means hands-off, empty gray means check in.

evidence.quote: Passive engagement - no relationship building. Flat emotional affect throughout.
evidence.insight: Anthony would be categorized as 'Passive' (responds to agent outreach but does not initiate platform engagement) or 'Silent' (if he stops responding to texts). The visual must distinguish these two states because they require different agent interventions.

evidence.quote: Diversity of opinion -- each person should have some private information, even if it's just an eccentric interpretation of the known facts.
evidence.insight: Surowiecki's diversity condition applies to the host portfolio: agents need to see the full diversity of engagement levels in their portfolio. A dashboard showing only 'active' and 'inactive' loses the granularity that makes the portfolio view useful. Four states (Active, Moderate, Passive, Silent) capture the spectrum.

The purple-to-gray gradient maps naturally to engagement level: deep purple = high engagement (brand-aligned, active), light gray = low engagement (faded, needs attention). This uses the existing token system without introducing new colors.

spacing: --spacing-sm (gap between engagement indicator and host name)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: The indicators are decorative/supplementary, not the sole carrier of information (host names and action items provide textual context). However, --secondary-purple on --bg-white = 5.3:1 (passes AA). --border-color (#e5e7eb) as an outline on --bg-white = 1.7:1 (borderline, but acceptable as the 'Silent' state is always accompanied by a text label in the row). For colorblind accessibility, each state also uses a different fill level (solid, half, quarter, empty) so the encoding works without color differentiation.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The engagement indicators form a vertical column in the agent dashboard's host list. The eye scans the column of circles before reading individual host names: a column of solid purple means 'portfolio is healthy,' any gray circles draw attention and trigger drill-down. The pattern exploits the pre-attentive processing of fill level and saturation.
elements.brand_alignment: Using the purple gradient for engagement level reinforces the idea that engagement with Split Lease exists on a spectrum, not as a binary. The gradual fade from brand purple to neutral gray visually communicates 'still part of the community, just quieter' rather than 'disengaged.' This aligns with the platform's inclusive positioning.

elements.title: SMS Notification Visual Language: Typographic Hierarchy for Glanceable Text Messages
elements.problem: The platform will send SMS messages to passive hosts across multiple journey phases (per works-0932-001 and communicates-0932-001). SMS is a constrained visual medium: no custom fonts, no colors, no layout control. The visual design challenge is to establish a consistent typographic hierarchy within pure text, so that passive hosts like Anthony can glance at a message and immediately identify: (1) what this is about, (2) what they need to do, and (3) how to do it. Without a deliberate typographic structure, SMS messages degrade into undifferentiated text blocks that passive hosts will skim past.
elements.solution: Establish a strict SMS typographic template that creates visual hierarchy through punctuation, capitalization, and line structure. Format: Line 1: [CATEGORY] in caps -- identifies the message type (LISTING, PROPOSAL, CHECK-IN, LEASE). Line 2: The key fact in natural case -- the one thing the host needs to know. Line 3: The action instruction -- what to reply. Example: 'PROPOSAL: Ariel wants Jun 1-Aug 30 at $3,000/mo. Reply OK to accept or ? for details.' The category label in caps creates a pseudo-header. The fact sentence uses natural case for readability. The action instruction is always the last line. This three-line structure is the SMS equivalent of the platform's scan order: header, body, CTA. For the platform's internal rendering of these messages (in notification logs, agent dashboards), the SMS template maps to the design system: CATEGORY in --font-inter --text-xs --font-weight-semibold --text-purple uppercase, fact in --font-dm --text-base --text-dark, action in --font-inter --text-sm --secondary-purple.

evidence.quote: This is a cell phone. I could probably texting pictures.
evidence.insight: Anthony's primary channel will be SMS. Every platform communication to Anthony will arrive as a text message on his cell phone. The visual hierarchy of these messages -- even though it's pure text -- determines whether Anthony reads, understands, and acts on them.

evidence.quote: For sixpence, you could buy a stamped and numbered ticket, where you filled in your name, your address, and your estimate.
evidence.insight: Galton's ticket was a structured text format: three fields (name, address, estimate) in a fixed layout. The SMS template mirrors this structured-text approach: three lines (category, fact, action) in a fixed layout. Structure within the text medium creates the visual hierarchy that the medium itself doesn't support natively.

evidence.quote: --font-inter: 'Inter'... Primary UI font. --font-dm: 'DM Sans'... Alternative display font. --text-xs: 11px, --text-sm: 12px, --text-base: 14px.
evidence.insight: When SMS messages are rendered inside the platform (notification logs, agent views), they should use the design system's fonts and sizes. The caps CATEGORY maps to Inter uppercase at --text-xs, creating visual consistency between the SMS the host receives and the platform's internal record of the same message.

spacing: --spacing-xs (line spacing between SMS template lines in platform rendering)
--spacing-md (padding around SMS preview cards in agent dashboard)
new_tokens_needed: --sms-category-style: combination token for uppercase, --text-xs, --font-weight-semibold, --text-purple -- for consistent SMS category rendering across all platform views

elements.contrast_requirements: SMS on device: controlled by device OS, not by the platform (white/dark mode depends on user's phone settings). In platform rendering: --text-purple (rgb(82, 31, 147)) on --bg-white = approximately 7.8:1 (passes AAA). --text-dark on --bg-white = 16.1:1 (passes AAA). --secondary-purple on --bg-white = 5.3:1 (passes AA).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: In SMS: CAPS category label is the first visual anchor (pre-attentive processing of uppercase). In platform rendering: the purple category label is the first visual anchor (color contrast draws the eye). In both cases, the eye should read: what type of message (category), what it says (fact), what to do (action) -- in that order, in under 3 seconds.
elements.brand_alignment: The SMS typographic template extends the Split Lease brand into the most constrained communication channel. By establishing a consistent structure, the host learns to recognize Split Lease messages by their format, not just their sender name. This builds platform identity even in a channel the platform does not visually control.
